text:
I've tried the `methods` function as suggested last week, but it doesn't quite tell me that the version that takes 2 args provides a default 3rd:
```julia> methods(scan)
# 2 methods for generic function "scan":
[1] scan(a::UInt8, b::UInt8) in Main at REPL[1]:1
[2] scan(a::UInt8, b::UInt8, acc) in Main at REPL[1]:1```
Bonus points for also being able to introspect the default value of `UInt64(0)`!

elements.text: function as suggested last week, but it doesn't quite tell me that the version that takes 2 args provides a default 3rd:

julia> methods(scan)
# 2 methods for generic function "scan":
[1] scan(a::UInt8, b::UInt8) in Main at REPL[1]:1
[2] scan(a::UInt8, b::UInt8, acc) in Main at REPL[1]:1
Bonus points for also being able to introspect the default value of

text: how about using `scan(a::UInt8, b::UInt8, acc::UInt64=0)` instead?
Sure, in that case how do I tell the last parameter is a default parameter?

elements.text: Sure, in that case how do I tell the last parameter is a default parameter?

text:
I don't think you can do that from just the methods list, as default arguments are basically syntactic sugar for adding helper methods:  `scan(a::UInt8, b::UInt8, acc::UInt64=0) = ...` is equivalent to
```scan(a::UInt8, b::UInt8, acc::UInt64) = ...
scan(a::UInt8, b::UInt8) = scan(a, b, acc)```

elements.text: I don't think you can do that from just the methods list, as default arguments are basically syntactic sugar for adding helper methods:

scan(a::UInt8, b::UInt8, acc::UInt64) = ...
scan(a::UInt8, b::UInt8) = scan(a, b, acc)
